contextId.occurrenceNote: The surface refers to the surface of the water in the pot. Jeremiah could see the water boiling. Alternate translation: "whose water is boiling" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: whose surface is churning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Setting their thrones "against all the walls that surround it" represents commanding their armies to destroy the walls surrounding Jerusalem. Alternate translation: "and they will command their armies to destroy the walls surrounding Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: against all the walls that surround it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Setting their thrones "against all the cities of Judah" represents commanding their armies to destroy all the cities of Judah. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: against all the cities of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents all the people of the land. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the whole land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Jacob's descendants. Alternate translation: "descendants of Jacob" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel's descendants, who had become the nation of Israel. Alternate translation: "the Israelites" or "the Israelite people group" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression refers to God himself, who is glorious. Alternate translation: "their glorious God" or "me, your glorious God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: their glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here false gods are spoken of in terms of what they cannot do. Alternate translation: "for false gods, which cannot help" or "for gods who cannot help" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for what cannot help

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "born in his master's home" is metonym for being born into slavery. Alternate translation: "Was he born a slave" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Was he born in his master's home

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents destroying the land in such a way that people will feel horror when they see it. Alternate translation: "destroyed Israel's land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: made his land a horror

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel's descendants. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 2:4](../02/04.md). Alternate translation: "the Israelites" or "the Israelite people group" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "tree" and "stone" represent idols carved from wood and stone. These words emphasize that the idol was made of ordinary things and is not worthy of worship. Alternate translation: "These people are the ones who say to a carved piece of wood, 'You are my father,' and to a carved stone, 'You gave birth to me.'" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: These are the ones who say to the tree, 'You are my father,' and to the stone, 'You gave birth to me.'

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "judgment" represents punishment. Alternate translation: "I will punish you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will bring down judgment on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "your eyes" represents looking at something. Alternate translation: "Look up" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Lift up your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The arrogance showing on a person's face is spoken of as if the face itself were arrogant. Alternate translation: "But the expression on your face shows that you arrogant, like the face of a prostitute" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you have the forehead of a prostitute

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "stones" and "trees" represent the stone and wood material that was used to create idols. The people's idol worship is spoken of as if they were committing adultery. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: she committed adultery with stones and trees

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the north represents the people of Israel who had been taken north to Assyria. Alternate translation: "Go and proclaim these words to the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Go and proclaim these words to the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents Yahweh's desire or will. The phrase "after my heart" is an idiom that describes people who do God's will. Alternate translation: "shepherds who do my will" or "shepherds who do what I want" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: shepherds after my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "come up in their hearts" represents thinking about it. Alternate translation: "They will no longer think of this matter" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: This matter will no longer come up in their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Yahweh's throne" represents the place from where Yahweh rules. Alternate translation: "This is from where Yahweh rules" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: This is Yahweh's throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Alternate translation: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" or "the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" or "the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "kingdom of Israel" or "people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the hills" represent the people's worship of false gods on the hills. The people now realize that those false gods could not guide and help them. Alternate translation: "The false gods that we worshiped on the hills could not guide us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Surely lies come from the hills

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "listened" represents obeying, and "the voice of Yahweh" represents what Yahweh has said. Alternate translation: "have not obeyed what Yahweh our God has said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: have not listened to the voice of Yahweh our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that 1) this is a command that emphasizes who they should return to. Alternate translation: "then come back to me" or "then worship me" 1) this is a repetition of the first phrase, which expresses a condition. Alternate translation: "if you will come back to me" or "if you will start worshiping me again" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: then it should be to me that you return

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "detestable things" refers to idols, which God hates. Alternate translation: "If you remove your disgusting idols from my presence" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: If you remove your detestable things from before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the nations" is a metonym for people of other nations. The word "him" refers to Yahweh. Since Yahweh is speaking, it can also be translated as "me." Alternate translation: "people of other nations will bless themselves in me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.glQuote: the nations will bless themselves in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bless themselves in him" is a metonym for asking Yahweh to bless them. Alternate translation: "the people of the nations will ask Yahweh to bless them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the nations will bless themselves in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents an enemy army that would come from the north. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents destroying the land, which would cause people who see it to be horrified. Alternate translation: "to destroy your land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to bring horror to your land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hearts" represent courage. Also "the hearts ... will die" represents losing courage and being afraid. Alternate translation: "the king and his officials will stop being courageous" or "the king and his officials will be terrified" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the hearts of the king and his officials will die

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents painful emotions, such as grief and fear. The phrase is repeated to express the intensity of the pain. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: My heart! My heart!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "city" represents the people living in the city. Alternate translation: "The people of every city" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Every city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "scarlet" represents expensive, red clothing. Alternate translation: "you wear expensive red clothing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you dress in scarlet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "trying to take your life away" represents trying to kill the people of Judah. Alternate translation: "They are trying to kill you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: they are trying to take away your life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hard faces represents the expression on their faces that shows that they are stubborn. The simile "harder than rock" shows that the people are extremely stubborn. Alternate translation: "They are extremely stubborn" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They make their faces harder than rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for a person's descendants. In this case it refers to the people of the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. Alternate translation: "For the people of Israel and Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: For the houses of Israel and Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "prophets" is a metonym that represents what the prophets say, and "wind" is a metaphor for something that does not do anything. Alternate translation: "The prophets words are just noisy wind" or "The prophets make noise like the wind, but what they prophesy will not happen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The prophets will become wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Its quiver" represents the enemy nation's army, and the arrows in the quiver represent the soldiers in the army. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Its quiver ... They are all soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Jacob's descendants. Translate "house of Jacob" as in [Jeremiah 2:4](../02/04.md). Alternate translation: "descendants of Jacob" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "cannot see" is a metonym for not understanding. Alternate translation: "you do not understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you cannot see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "cannot hear" represents not understanding. "Alternate translation: "you do not understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you cannot hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "wickedness" represents disaster and the people who will cause it. Alternate translation: "enemies will come from the north and cause disaster to happen to you" or "enemies coming from the north will destroy you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: wickedness is appearing from the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of kings leading their armies to destroy the land, as if they were shepherds leading their sheep to eat grass. Alternate translation: "like a shepherd each king will lead his army" or "each king will lead his army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: each man will shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: The end of the day is spoken of in terms of its light becoming dark. Alternate translation: "the day is ending" or "it is beginning to get dark" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the daylight is fading away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God speaks to the people of Jerusalem as if he were speaking to the city itself. Alternate translation: "Accept discipline, you people of Jerusalem ... make your land into a ruin, an uninhabited land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Accept discipline, Jerusalem ... make you into a ruin, an uninhabited land

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Accept discipline" here is a metaphor for learning from discipline. Alternate translation: "Learn from your discipline" or "When I punish you, learn to do what is right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Accept discipline

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences are telling the people of other nations to witness what Yahweh will do to the rebellious people of Judah. Alternate translation: "Therefore, you people of other nations, listen! You witnesses, see what will happen to my people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.glQuote: Therefore, nations, listen! See, you witnesses, what will happen to them.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "swords of the enemy" represents the enemy with their swords ready to attack. The abstract noun "terror" refers to things that cause people to be frightened and can be translated with an adjective. Alternate translation: "For the enemy is everywhere with their swords and everyone else is terrified" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: for the swords of the enemy and terror are all around

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here pouring out innocent blood represents killing those not deserving death. Alternate translation: "kill innocent people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: pour out innocent blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here walking after is a metonym for following after with the intent to serve and obey. Alternate translation: "serve other gods" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: walk after other gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here walking after is a metonym for following after with the intent to serve and obey. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 7:6](../07/06.md). Alternate translation: "serve other gods" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: walk after other gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for Yahweh's temple. It can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: "house that belongs to me" or "temple where you worship me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: house that is called by my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for Yahweh's temple. It can be expressed in active form. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 7:10](../07/10.md). Alternate translation: "this house that belongs to me" or "this temple where you worship me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: this house that is called by my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here listening to Yahweh's voice means to both hear his words and obey what he says. Alternate translation: "Hear and obey what I say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Listen to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the voice of Yahweh" represents what Yahweh has said. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:25](../03/25.md). Alternate translation: "what Yahweh its God has said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the voice of Yahweh its God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people of Judah. Alternate translation: "people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sons of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "detestable things" refers to idols, which God hates. Alternate translation: "their disgusting idols" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: their detestable things

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for Yahweh's temple. It can be expressed in active form. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 7:10](../07/10.md). Alternate translation: "house that belongs to me" or "temple where they worship me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: house that is called by my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "mind" refers to Yahweh's thoughts. Alternate translation: "nor did I ever think about it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: nor did it enter my mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for what happens at marriage ceremonies. Alternate translation: "and people celebrating marriage" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the sound of the groom and the sound of the bride

contextId.occurrenceNote: The pen represents the words that the scribes write. Alternate translation: "The false things that the scribes write" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The deceitful pen of the scribes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people's speech is represented by their "mouths." Alternate translation: "They speak, saying that they want peace with their neighbors" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: With their mouths they proclaim peace with their neighbors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh's "voice" represents what he says. Alternate translation: "they do not pay attention to the things I tell them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: they do not listen to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people's "stubborn hearts" represent their stubborn desires and stubborn will. Also, here "walked" represents living. Alternate translation: "they have been stubborn and lived the way they want to live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: they have walked by their stubborn hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "sword" refers to an enemy army. Alternate translation: "I will send an army of soldiers to fight against them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will send out a sword after them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for Yahweh causing the people's enemies to destroy them. Alternate translation: "I have caused their enemies to completely destroy them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I have completely destroyed them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "send out for" is an idiom. Alternate translation: "Send people out to get women who are skilled at mourning" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Send out for women skilled at lamenting

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "nations" refers to the people who live in these places. Foreigners being uncircumcised was a sign that they were not in Yahweh's covenant. Alternate translation: "For the people of these nations did not enter into a covenant with Yahweh through circumcision" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: For all these nations are uncircumcised

contextId.occurrenceNote: The "heart" represents a person's will and desires. An "uncircumcised heart" represents the character of a person that does not follow Yahweh and his laws. Also, the "house" of Israel refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "all the people of Israel are only circumcised on the outside and have not changed their hearts" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: all the house of Israel has an uncircumcised heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "house" of Israel represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh's "name" refers to himself and his reputation. Alternate translation: "you are very powerful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: your name is great in power

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is represented by his "voice" to emphasize his speech. The phrase "the roar of waters" refers to loud storms. Alternate translation: "His voice causes the storms in the sky" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: His voice makes the roar of waters in the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jacob" represents the people of Israel. God being their "portion" is an idiom that means that they worship him. Alternate translation: "the portion of Israel" or "whom the people of Israel worship" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the portion of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "voice" here is a metonym for what the speaker says with the voice, and "listen" is a metonym for "obey." Alternate translation: "Obey what I say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Listen to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "voice" here is a metonym for what the speaker says with the voice, and "listen" is a metonym for "obey." Alternate translation: "Obey what I say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Listen to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "The kingdom of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "cities of Judah" represents the people who live in them. Alternate translation: "The people who live in the cities of Judah and in Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The cities of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The heart is a metonym for what a person feels and desires and "the mind" is a metonym for what a person thinks and decides. Alternate translation: "a person's feelings and thoughts" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the heart and the mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "sword" represents battle. Alternate translation: "will die in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: will die by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mouths" represents what a person says. And, "hearts" represents what a person thinks or feels. Also, being loyal is spoken of as if it were being near a person, and being disloyal is spoken of as if it were being far away from a person. Alternate translation: "They always say good things about you, but they do not love or respect you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You are near to them in their mouths, but far away from their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "heart" represents a person's thoughts and true feelings. Alternate translation: "my thoughts" or "my inner feelings" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hands" represents control. Alternate translation: "to be conquered by her enemies" or "over to the control of her enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: into the hands of her enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "shepherds" refers to their sheep. Alternate translation: "Many shepherds have allowed their sheep to destroy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Many shepherds have destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Judah and Jerusalem refer to the people who live there. Alternate translation: "of the people of Judah and Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: of Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" or "the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" or "the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the throne that the king of Judah sits on is represented as "David's throne." Alternate translation: "the kings who sit on Judah's throne" or "the kings of the nation of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the kings who sit on David's throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Judah" represents the people who live there. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "The enemies will take all of the people of Judah captive into exile" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: All Judah will be taken captive, completely taken captive

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Judah" represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: "Let the people of Judah mourn" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Let Judah mourn

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh's "name" refers to his reputation. Alternate translation: "for the sake of your reputation" or "in order that everyone can see that you are very great and keep your promises" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for the sake of your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here war is represented by the "sword" which was the common weapon used in battle. Alternate translation: "by war" or "by battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: by sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents war, and to "see" represents experiencing. Alternate translation: "You will not experience any war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: You will not see the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to speaking with Yahweh's power and authority or as his representative. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to speaking with Yahweh's power and authority or as his representative. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 14:14](../14/14.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "sword" represents war. Alternate translation: "there will be no war ... perish by war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: there will be no sword ... perish by sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "sword" represents war. Alternate translation: "famine and war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: famine and sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "diseases" represent the people who have these diseases because of their starvation. Alternate translation: "there are the ones who are sick because of famine" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: there are the diseases that are caused by famine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh's "name" refers to his reputation. Alternate translation: "For the sake of your reputation" or "In order that everyone can see that you are very great and keep your promises" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: For the sake of your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's "throne" is represented by Zion, that is Jerusalem. His "throne" also represents the place where he rules as king. Alternate translation: "do disgrace Zion where you glorious throne is" or "do not disgrace Zion, where you rule as king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: your glorious throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "sword" represents war. To be "for the sword" means that God has appointed them to die in war. Alternate translation: "those whom I have appointed to die in war should go to die in war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: those who are for the sword should go to the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "sword" refers to the enemy soldiers. Alternate translation: "the enemy soldiers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jerusalem" refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: "for you people who live in Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for you, Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power. Alternate translation: "I will use my power to strike you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will strike you with my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "sword" represents the enemy soldiers. This means that Yahweh will allow the enemy solider to kill any of her children that remain. Alternate translation: "I will allow the enemy soldiers to kill those of her children that remain alive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: I will give those who remain to the sword in the presence of their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "heart" represents a person emotions and feelings. Alternate translation: "what I love most" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the delight of my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" represents control. Alternate translation: "the control of the wicked ... the control of the tyrant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of the wicked ... the hand of the tyrant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "cup" represents the drink that the cup holds. Alternate translation: "none must give a comforting drink" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: none must give a comforting cup

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "nations" represents the people from the nations. Alternate translation: "The people from the nations will go to you" or "The people of the nations will come to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-go]])
contextId.glQuote: The nations will go to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "deceit" refers to false gods. Alternate translation: "our ancestors inherited nothing but false gods" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: our ancestors inherited deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" refers to power and authority. The two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize Yahweh's great power. Alternate translation: "my great power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: my hand and my power

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "name" refers to Yahweh's entire person. Alternate translation: "they will know that I am Yahweh, the true God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: they will know that Yahweh is my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "flesh" represents humans. Alternate translation: "he depends on mere humans for strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he makes flesh his strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "heart" refers to the thoughts and emotions. Alternate translation: "turns his devotion away from Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: turns his heart away from Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "heart" refers to the minds and thoughts of people. Alternate translation: "The human mind is more deceitful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The heart is more deceitful

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hearts" represents the emotions. Alternate translation: "who tests the emotions" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who tests the hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the throne that the king of Judah sits on is represented as "David's throne." See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 13:13](../13/13.md). Alternate translation: "those who sit on Judah's throne" or "the kings of the nation of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: those who sit on David's throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "eyes" represents sight and sight represents one's opinion. Alternate translation: "that he thought was good" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: that was pleasing in his eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "kingdom of Israel" or "people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "it" refers to a nation or kingdom, which is a metonym for the people in that nation or kingdom. The word "eyes" represents seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: "if the people of that nation do things that I consider to be evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: if it does evil in my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "voice" represents the words that Yahweh speaks. Here, "not listening" is an idiom that means that they do not obey. Alternate translation: "not obeying what I say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: not listening to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "heart" represents the person's mind or will. Alternate translation: "what his evil, stubborn mind desires" or "whatever evil things that we stubbornly want to do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: what his evil, stubborn heart desires

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "fury" represents the punishment that Yahweh intended to inflict upon them. Jeremiah speaks of Yahweh not punishing them as if he were turning his fury away from them. Alternate translation: "so that you would not punish them in your anger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to cause your fury to turn away from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hands" represents power. Alternate translation: "cause those who use the sword to have power over them" or "cause them to die in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: give them to the hands of those who use the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "innocent blood" represents the murder of innocent people. Yahweh speaks of murdering many people as filling a place with blood. Alternate translation: "murdered many innocent people in this place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: filled this place with innocent blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "mind" refers to Yahweh's thoughts. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 7:31](../07/31.md). Alternate translation: "nor did I ever think about it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: nor did it enter my mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) that Pashhur himself beat Jeremiah or 2) that Pashhur ordered other men to beat Jeremiah. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Pashhur beat Jeremiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" refers to power. Alternate translation: "I will enable the king of Babylon to conquer all of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will give all of Judah into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Placing things in people's hands represents  giving thing to the people or allowing the people to take the things. Alternate translation: "I will give these things to your enemies" or "I will allow your enemies to take possession of these things"  (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will place these things in the hand of your enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "word" refers to the message of Yahweh. The words "reproach" and "mocking" can be translated with verbal phrases. Alternate translation: "people reproach and mock me every day because I proclaim Yahweh's message" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh's word has become for me reproach and mocking every day

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "I will never mention Yahweh or say anything about him" or 2) the word "name" represents authority. Alternate translation: "I will no longer speak as his messenger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will not speak any longer in his name

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "mind" is a metonym for what a person thinks and decides, and the word "heart" is a metonym for what a person feels and desires. Alternate translation: "know every person's thoughts and feelings" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: see the mind and the heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" represents power. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "those whom evildoers oppress with their power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: those who are oppressed from the hand of evildoers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) the instruments of war refers to the soldiers who carry them and "hand" represents control. Alternate translation: "the soldiers that you command" or 2) the instruments of war are literal weapons and "your hand" represent both the king and his soldiers. Alternate translation: "the weapons that you and your soldiers carry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the instruments of war that are in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this refers to the battle in which swords are used. Alternate translation: "the war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" refers to the power of their enemies over them. Alternate translation: "into the power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: into the hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) this is a metonym for death in battle. Alternate translation: "in battle" or 2) they will be killed by literal swords. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: with the edge of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Death by the sword refers to death in battle. Alternate translation: "in battle and by famine and plague" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: by the sword, famine, and plague

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents the power of the king to destroy the city. Alternate translation: "into the power of the king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: into the hand of the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to king and his family. Alternate translation: "the king of Judah and his family" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of the king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the same people as "the house of the king of Judah." All of the kings of Judah were descendants of David. Alternate translation: "Descendants of David" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: House of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" refers to power. Alternate translation: "the power of the one who oppresses them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of the oppressor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the hand" refers to power or control. Alternate translation: "the power of the oppressor" or "the one who would harm him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of the oppressor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The metonym "throne" refers to kingly authority like David had. Alternate translation: "kings, ruling like David before them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: kings sitting on David's throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is a metonym that describes the kings as powerful and wealthy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: riding in a chariot and on horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) this refers to the royal palace where the king lived or 2) "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, who were the royal line of the kings of Judah. Alternate translation: "the royal dynasty of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of the king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Jehoahaz (verse 11) and his family. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: his house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" is a metonym for seeing and "heart" is a metonym for thinking. Alternate translation: "you never look for or think about anything except ... crushing of others" or "you only look for and think about ways to cheat others and pour out innocent blood, and to oppress and crush others" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: there is nothing in your eyes and heart except worry ... crushing of others

contextId.occurrenceNote: Listening is a metonym for obeying. Alternate translation: "you have not obeyed me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you have not listened to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: A signet ring was used by a king to place his seal of authority on documents. The signet ring therefore represents authority to rule. The right hand also represents authority to rule. Alternate translation: "the signet ring on my right hand that represented my authority to be king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the signet on my right hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "hand" represents power and control. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to the hand of

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting on a throne is a metonym for ruling as king. Alternate translation: "become king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sit on David's throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "land" refers to the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: "for all the people in the nation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Judah" refers to the people of Judah. Alternate translation: "the people of Judah will be rescued" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah will be rescued

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Israel" refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "the people of Israel will live in security" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Israel will live in security

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet speaks of his heart being broken and his bones trembling because he is afraid of the judgment that will result from the lies of the false prophets. Alternate translation: "I have great fear for what will happen because of the false prophets" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Regarding the prophets, my heart is broken in me, and all of my bones tremble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here trembling is associated with fear. Alternate translation: "I am very afraid" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all of my bones tremble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "minds" refers to the thoughts of the false prophets. Alternate translation: "visions that they imagined" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: visions from their own minds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mouth" refers to what Yahweh said. Alternate translation: "not what Yahweh said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: not from Yahweh's mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart's intentions" refers to the things that Yahweh wanted to happen. Alternate translation: "completed and accomplished all the punishment that he had planned" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: carried out and brought into being his heart's intentions

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to speaking with Yahweh's power and authority or as his representative. See how you translated this phrase in [Jeremiah 14:14](../14/14.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "name" refers to the whole being of Yahweh. Alternate translation: "forget me ... forgot me" or "forget who I am ... forgot who I am" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: forget my name ... forgot my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Baal's name" refers to the god Baal. Alternate translation: "leading my people to worship Baal instead of me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in favor of Baal's name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "tongues" is a metonym for the ability to speak. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who use their tongues

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" is a metonym for the family that lives inside it. Alternate translation: "his family" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: his house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "set my eyes" means he will see them. Seeing them is a metonym for caring for them. Alternate translation: "I will bless them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will set my eyes on them for good

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" refers to war or enemy armies. Alternate translation: "I will send enemy armies" or "I will send out war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will send out sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "nations" represents the people of the nations. Yahweh speaks of people experiencing his fury as if they were to drink the wine that is in the cup. Alternate translation: "make all the people of the nations ... drink the wine" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: make all the nations ... drink it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "sword" represents war. Alternate translation: "because of the wars that I am causing to happen among them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: before the sword that I am sending out among them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "nations" represents the people of the nations. Alternate translation: "I made all the people of the nations ... drink the wine from the cup" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I made all the nations ... drink it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "nations" represents the people of the nations. Alternate translation: "People from other nations also had to drink the wine from the cup" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Other nations also had to drink it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the cup" is a metonym for the wine that it contains. Alternate translation: "all of these people had to drink the wine from the cup in Yahweh's hand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all of them had to drink the cup from Yahweh's hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "sword" represents war. Alternate translation: "before the wars that I am causing to happen among you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: before the sword that I am sending among you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Jerusalem and can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "the city that I have called by my name" or "Jerusalem, which I have called by my name" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the city that is called by my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "sword" represents war. Yahweh speaks of declaring war against the people as if he were calling a sword against them. Alternate translation: "I am declaring war against all the inhabitants of the land" or "I am bringing war against all the inhabitants of the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am calling a sword against all the inhabitants of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is a metonym for heaven. Alternate translation: "from heaven" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from the heights

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "flesh" represents humanity. Alternate translation: "on all mankind" or "on all people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: on all flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: What Yahweh would turn the city into is a metonym for what people would use the city for. Alternate translation: "I will make this city so that people will ask me to destroy others the way I have destroyed this city" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will turn this city into a curse

contextId.occurrenceNote: Blood is a metonym for violent death, and to bring blood on someone is to make them guilty of violent death. Alternate translation: "you are making yourselves and this city and its inhabitants guilty of the violent death of an innocent person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you are bringing innocent blood on yourselves and on this city and its inhabitants

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ear is a metonym for what the ear hears. Alternate translation: "for you to hear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for your ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person's name is a metonym for his authority. Alternate translation: "with the authority of Yahweh our God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in the name of Yahweh our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land is a metonym for the people who live there. Alternate translation: "all the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "city" and "land" are metonyms for the people who live there. Alternate translation: "prophesied that bad things would happen to the people who lived in this city and this land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: prophesied against this city and this land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises. Ahikam was not a soldier, so he probably was able to talk to people and change their minds. Alternate translation: "Ahikam ... was able to help Jeremiah" or "Ahikam ... was able to keep the people from harming Jeremiah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of Ahikam ... was with Jeremiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "Ahikam did not allow the people to have the power to put Jeremiah to death" or "the people could not kill Jeremiah because Ahikam did not give them the power to" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: he was not given into the hand of the people to be put to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises, and the word "lands" is a metonym for the people who live in those lands. Alternate translation: "I ... am putting the people who live in all these lands under the power of Nebuchadnezzar ... servant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I ... am giving all these lands into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar ... servant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "him" refers to Nebuchadnezzar who represents the kingdom of Babylon. Alternate translation: "will defeat Babylon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: subdue him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand here could be a metonym for Nebuchadnezzar's power, or it could be a metonym for Nebuchadnezzar's armies. Alternate translation: "I have used Nebuchadnezzar's power to destroy it" or "I have enabled Nebuchadnezzar's armies to destroy i" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I have destroyed it by his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "in my name" represents speaking with Yahweh's power and authority or as his representative. Here these prophets claim that they received their message from Yahweh, but that had not. The abstract noun "deceit" can be translated as the verb "deceiving." Alternate translation: "they say they are speaking for me when they prophesy, but they are deceiving you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: they are prophesying deceit in my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "nation" is a metonym for the people of that nation. Alternate translation: "the people of every nation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: every nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The peace of the city is a metonym for the people living in peace. Alternate translation: "Do everything you can so the people of the city live in peace" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Seek the peace of the city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Praying is spoken of as calling out with a loud voice. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you will call to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wanting to know what Yahweh requires is spoken of as trying to find where Yahweh is. Alternate translation: "you will want to do what I require you to do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you will seek me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for ruling as king. Alternate translation: "the king who rules the Israelites as David did" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the king who sits on the throne of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "sword" is a metonym for war. The sword, famine, and disease are spoken of as people who can obey Yahweh's command to harm the Israelites. Alternate translation: "I am going to punish them by having them die in war, from hunger, and from illness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: I am about to send sword, famine, and disease on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "name" is a metonym for the person. Alternate translation: "liars who tell you that they are speaking my words to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who prophesy falsely to you in my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: "I will allow Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon to conquer them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I am about to put them into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "name" refers to a person's authority and reputation. Alternate translation: "based on your own authority and reputation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in your own name

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name Jacob is a metonym for the man's descendants. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "for the descendants of Jacob, but I will rescue them from it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: for Jacob, but he will be rescued from it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for one of David's descendants. Alternate translation: "a man descended from their King David" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: David their king

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Jacob" and "Israel" are the two names of the ancestor of the Israelites, and these names are metonyms for the Israelites. Alternate translation: "descendants of Jacob ... you Israelite people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my servant Jacob ... Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jacob's name is a metonym for his descendants. Yahweh speaks to Jacob as if he were speaking to another person. You may need to make explicit to where Jacob will return. Alternate translation: "Jacob will return to his own land ... he will be secure" or "The descendants of Jacob will return ... they will be secure" or "You descendants of Jacob will return ... you will be secure" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Jacob will return ... he will be secure

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place name "Zion" is a metonym for the people who live in Zion. Alternate translation: "No one cares about the people of Zion" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: No one cares for this Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The places where people live are metonyms for the people who live in those places. Alternate translation: "I am about bring back the fortunes of the descendants of Jacob, and I will have compassion on them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I am about to bring back the fortunes of Jacob's tents and have compassion on his homes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "sword" is a metonym for war. Alternate translation: "who have survived the war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who have survived the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah speaks of himself as if he were the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh appeared to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rachel was the wife of Jacob/Israel and was the mother of the tribes of Joseph and Benjamin. Her name is a metonym for the women of Israel who are crying because the Babylonians have killed their children or taken them away. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: It is Rachel weeping for her children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim was the ancestor of the largest tribe in Israel. His name is a metonym for the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "I have certainly heard the descendants of Ephraim sorrowing" or "I have certainly heard the people of Israel sorrowing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I have certainly heard Ephraim sorrowing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name of the man Judah is a metonym for the land on which his descendants, the people of the tribe of Judah, live, and the cities of Judah are spoken of as if they were the family of the man Judah, all of them living "there," in the land of Judah. Alternate translation: "it will be as if the land were a house in which Judah lived with his family" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah and all its cities will live together there

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the people of Israel and the people of Judah. The house in turn is spoken of as if it were a field in which Yahweh would sow seed, and the people and the animals they raise for food, milk, and skins are spoken of as if they are that seed. Alternate translation: "I will cause the people of Israel and Judah to become many people with many animals" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will sow the houses of Israel and Judah with the descendants of man and beast

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" or "the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" or "the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" or "the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Zedekiah do this. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Zedekiah king of Judah had imprisoned him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "I will certainly put him under the control of the king of Babylon" or "I will certainly allow the king of Babylon to do whatever he wants with him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: he will certainly be given into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "raised arm" is a metonym for the strength of the arm, so the words "your great strength" and "your raised arm" form a doublet. Alternate translation: "by your great power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: by your great strength and with your raised arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "guilt" is a metonym for Yahweh punishing people because they are guilty of doing evil things. Yahweh punishing people is spoken of as if he were pouring a large container full of liquid or small objects into people's laps as they sit. Alternate translation: "you punish children for the sins of their parents" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: pour the guilt of men into the laps of their children after them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Open eyes are a metonym for what the person sees. How a person lives is spoken of as if he were walking on a path. Alternate translation: "You see everything that people do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for your eyes are open to all the ways of people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "name" refers to God's reputation. Alternate translation: "you have made yourself famous" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you have made your name famous

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "strong hand" is a metonym for strength, and the phrase "raised arm" is a metonym for the strength of the arm, so the phrases "strong hand" and "raised arm" form a doublet. Alternate translation: "by your great strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: with a strong hand, with a raised arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: The voice is a metonym for the message the speaker gives. Alternate translation: "But they did not obey what you said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: But they did not obey your voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "sword" is a metonym for war, where soldiers use swords. Alternate translation: "because soldiers will attack" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: because of sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" means power or control. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "you have given Jerusalem to the Chaldean army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: the city has been given into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the city as if it were a small object that he could put into a person's hand. The word "hand" is a metonym for the power that the hand puts into action. Alternate translation: "put this city under the power of the Chaldeans" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: give this city into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "eyes" represents what God sees. Possible meanings are 1) "doing what I consider evil" or 2) "doing evil knowing that I am watching" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: doing evil before my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "city" is a metonym for the people that live there. The words "wrath" and "fury" mean basically the same thing and emphasize how very angry he is. Alternate translation: "the people of Jerusalem have made me very angry since the day they built their city" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: this city has been a provocation of my wrath and fury since the day that they built it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mind" refers to Yahweh's thoughts. Alternate translation: "I never thought at all" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: It never entered my mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" means power or control. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has given it to the king of Babylon" or "Yahweh has given the king of Babylon the power to rule it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: It is given into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel will want to work together to honor Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: one heart and one way to honor me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" is a metonym for power or control. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has given it to the Chaldeans" or "Yahweh has given the Chaldeans power over it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: It has been given into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for people dying violently when soldiers kill with swords. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city is a metonym for the people who live in the city. Alternate translation: "the people who live in this city ... do for the people who live there ... give to the people who live there" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: this city ... do for it ... give to it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "song" is a metonym for the object about which people will sing the song. Alternate translation: "something about which all the people groups of the earth will sing songs of praise and honor to me, Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: a song of praise and honor for all the nations of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "land" is a metonym for the people who live on the land. Alternate translation: "I will again cause things to go well for the people who live on the land" or "I will cause the people who live on the land to live well again" See how similar words are translated in [Jeremiah 29:14](../29/14.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will restore the fortunes of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people who live in Judah. Alternate translation: "the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: the nation of Israel (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: These towns' names are metonyms for the people who live in the towns. Alternate translation: "the people of Judah ... the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah ... Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The throne is a metonym for the king. Alternate translation: "to be king over the house of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to sit on the throne of the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The throne is a metonym for the king who sits on the throne. Alternate translation: "to rule the kingdom I have given to him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to sit on his throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sight is a metonym for thinking. Alternate translation: "they no longer think of my people as a nation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my people ... are no longer a nation in their sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all the towns around Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all of her cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" is a metonym for the control that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: "under the control of the king of Babylon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" is a metonym for the control that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: "You will not escape from his control" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: You will not escape from his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "sword" is a metonym for dying in war. Alternate translation: "You will not die in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: You will not die by the sword.

contextId.occurrenceNote: To incline the ear, to lean the head toward the speaker so as to hear better, is a metonym for paying attention to what the speaker is saying. Alternate translation: "did not ... pay attention to what I said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: did not ... incline their ears to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Eyes" here is a metonym for someone's opinion or idea. Alternate translation: "what I consider to be right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: right in my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person's name is a metonym for what people think of him. Alternate translation: "stopped doing what was right and did evil things that have made people think that I am evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: turned and polluted my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for soldiers who carry swords. Alternate translation: "enemy soldiers to kill you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" here is a metonym for the power or control that the enemies will exercise using their hands. AT; "I will allow their enemies to have complete control over them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will give them into the hand of their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hands" represents control. Alternate translation: "to be conquered by their enemies" or "over to the control of their enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: into the hand of their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "voice" is a metonym for the command that Jonadab spoke. Alternate translation: "the command of Jonadab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the voice of Jonadab

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "iniquity" and "sin" are metonyms for the persons who commit iniquity and sin. Alternate translation: "forgive them for their iniquity and their sin" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
