contextId.glQuote: forgive their iniquity and their sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting on the throne is a metonym for ruling as king. See how you translated "sits on the throne of David" in [Jeremiah 29:16](../29/16.md). Alternate translation: "will ever rule the Israelites as David did" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: will ever sit on the throne of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. This can be translated in active form. See how you translated similar words in [Jeremiah 32:4](../32/04.md). Alternate translation: "I will certainly put you under the control of the king of Babylon" or "I will certainly allow the king of Babylon to do whatever he wants with you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: You will be given into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "I will allow the army of the king of Babylon to conquer Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: This city will be given into the hand of the army of the king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Weak hands are a metonym for a person who is afraid. Alternate translation: "he is causing the soldiers and all the people in the city to lose courage" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he is weakening the hands of the fighting men who remain in this city, and the hands of all the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand has. Alternate translation: "you are able do whatever you want with him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he is in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" refers to the men's control or power. Alternate translation: "I will not ... allow those men to capture you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will not ... give you into the hand of those men

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name of the people group is metonym for the people of that group. Alternate translation: "God of the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: God of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: "you will not escape from their power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you will not escape from their hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. Alternate translation: "will not escape from their power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: will not escape from their hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" is a metonym for the power or control that the hand exercises. This can be translated in active form. The reader should probably understand that many people will help the king do this. Alternate translation: "The army of the king of Babylon will capture you and will burn the city" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: You will be captured by the hand of the king of Babylon, and this city will be burned

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" refers to power or control. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "the men you fear will not harm you" or "I will not allow anyone to put you under the control of the people whom you fear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: you will not be given into the hand of the men whom you fear

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Eyes" here is a metonym for what the person thinks. Alternate translation: "it is what you consider to be right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: it is good in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Eyes" here is a metonym for what the person thinks. Alternate translation: "it is what you consider to be right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: it is good in your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "land" represents the people. Alternate translation: "in charge of the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in charge of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Having things in the hands here is probably a metaphor for carrying those things or having them in their possession. Alternate translation: "in their possession" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here King Asa represents his men. Alternate translation: "that King Asa ordered his men to dig" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: that King Asa dug

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "land" represents the people. Alternate translation: "in charge of the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in charge of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" represents what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: "what Yahweh our God says" or "we will obey Yahweh our God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the voice of Yahweh our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" refers to power and authority. Alternate translation: "rescue you from his power" or "rescue you from him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: rescue you from his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" represents a command. To not obey is like the people did not hear Yahweh's command. Alternate translation: "if you do not obey my commands, even though I am Yahweh, your God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: if you do not listen to my voice, the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being hungry for food is used to describe famine. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: we will not go hungry for food

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the sword" represents war. The Israelites experiencing war even if they go to Egypt is spoken of as if the sword would chase after the people catch up with them. Alternate translation: "you will experience the terrible results of war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the sword that you fear will overtake you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" represents what Yahweh commanded. Alternate translation: "to what Yahweh your God commanded" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents war. Alternate translation: "you will die in warfare" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you will die by sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. Alternate translation: "to give us over to the Chaldeans" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to deliver us into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" represents commands. And here "to listen" means "to obey." Alternate translation: "would not obey Yahweh's command" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: refused to listen to Yahweh's voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both the king's "throne" and "pavilion" are used to refer to his royal authority. Alternate translation: "I will cause him to rule as king over the people of Egypt. He will place his throne and pavilion over these stones you have buried" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will place his throne over these stones that you, Jeremiah, have buried. Nebuchadnezzar will place his pavilion over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "he" refers to Nebuchadnezzar who represents his whole army. Alternate translation: "Nebuchadnezzar's army will come" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he will come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents battle. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Everyone will die in battle whom I have decided will die in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Anyone who is assigned to the sword will be given to the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "I" refers to Yahweh. This represents Yahweh sending the Babylonian army to light a fire. Alternate translation: "Then I will cause the Babylonian army to light a fire" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Then I will light a fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Nebuchadnezzar represents his army. Alternate translation: "Nebuchadnezzar's army will ... They will" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Nebuchadnezzar will ... He will

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "nations" represent the people. Alternate translation: "all the people of all the nations of the earth will curse you and hate you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you will be a curse and a reproach among all the nations of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jerusalem" represents the people. Alternate translation: "I punished the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I punished Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents enemies carrying weapons. Alternate translation: "by causing enemies to kill some of them, others to starve to death, and others to die because of disease" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: with the sword, with famine, and with the plague

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "in Yahweh's name" means "in Yahweh's authority" or "as Yahweh's representative." Alternate translation: "We will not obey this message that you say Yahweh told you to tell us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: About the word that you have told us in Yahweh's name—we will not listen to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents enemies carrying weapons. Alternate translation: "enemy soldiers were killing some of us and some of us were dying of hunger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: were dying by sword and famine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" refers to Yahweh's commands. Alternate translation: "you would not obey his commands" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you would not listen to his voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Judah" represents the people. Alternate translation: "all the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Judah" represents the people. Alternate translation: "all the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "name" represents the whole being of Yahweh. And, "mouth" represents the whole person. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "No person of Judah living in the land of Egypt will ever call upon me again" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: My name will no longer be called upon by the mouths of any of the men of Judah in all the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents enemies carrying weapons. Alternate translation: "Then those whom the enemies do not kill" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Then the survivors of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. Alternate translation: "I will allow the enemies who want to kill Pharaoh Hophra, the king of Egypt, to defeat him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I am about to give Pharaoh Hophra king of Egypt into the hand of his enemies and into the hand of those who seek to kill him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. And, Nebuchadnezzar represents his whole army. The phrase "sought his life" is an idiom that means to want to kill someone. Alternate translation: "when I allowed the army of Nebuchadnezzar to defeat Zedekiah king of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: when I gave Zedekiah king of Judah into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, his enemy who sought his life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Nebuchadnezzar represents his army. Alternate translation: "that the army of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Egypt" represents all the people of Egypt. Alternate translation: "The Egyptians rise ... The Egyptians say ... We will" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Egypt rises ... Egypt says ... I will

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "horses" and "chariots" represent the soldiers who use horses and chariots in battle. The leaders of Egypt are ordering their soldiers to start the battle. Alternate translation: "Go up to battle, you soldiers on horses. Fight furiously, you soldiers in chariots" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Go up, horses. Be angry, you chariots

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "earth" is a metonym for the people of the earth and a generalization for the people who know what has happened to Egypt. All the people of the earth hearing the Egyptians crying is spoken of as if their laments filled the earth. Alternate translation: "All the people of the earth hear you crying" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The earth is filled with your laments

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Nebuchadnezzar represents his army. Alternate translation: "when the army of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "land" represents the people. Alternate translation: "the people of Egypt" or "the Egyptians" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "sword" here represents soldiers carrying weapons. The enemy soliders killing people is spoken of as if their swords were devouring people. Alternate translation: "your enemies will kill people all around you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the sword will devour those around you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents the enemy soldiers who are carrying weapons. Alternate translation: "Let us run away from our enemies because they are killing us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Let us leave this sword that is beating us down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "I, Yahweh, will allow the people from the north to defeat the Egyptians" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: She will be given into the hand of people from the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Egypt" represents the people. Alternate translation: "all the people of Egypt and the gods they worship" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Egypt and her gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. The phrase "seeking their lives" is an idiom that mean to want to kill someone. Alternate translation: "I will allow those who are wanting to kill them to defeat them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I am giving them into the hand of the ones seeking their lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents power or control. "Nebuchadnezzar ... his servants" names specifically "the ones seeking their lives." Alternate translation: "that is, I will allow Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and his servants to defeat the Egyptians" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: and into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and his servants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Pharaoh" represents the Egyptians army. Alternate translation: "before Pharaoh's army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: before Pharaoh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Moab" represents the people. Alternate translation: "To the people of Moab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: To Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Nebo" represents the people. Alternate translation: "How terrible it is for the people of Nebo, for their city is devastated" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Woe to Nebo, for it has been devastated

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Kiriathaim has been humiliated" represents the people being humiliated. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "The enemy has captured the city of Kiriathaim and humiliated the people who live there" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymyand figs-activepassive]] and
contextId.glQuote: Kiriathaim has been humiliated

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fortress has been disgraced" represents the people being disgraced. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "The enemy has destroyed the fortress in Kiriathaim and disgraced its people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymyand figs-activepassive]] and
contextId.glQuote: Her fortress has been disgraced

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents the enemy army carrying weapons. Alternate translation: "your enemies will chase after you and kill you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: a sword will go after you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) the children who lived in Moab or 2) "children" is a metonym that represents the people of Moab in general. Alternate translation: "The people of Moab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Her children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "city" represents the people. Alternate translation: "no people from any city will escape" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: no city will escape

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "valley" and "plain" represent the cities and the people in those places Alternate translation: "So the enemy army will destroy everything in the valleys and on the plains" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: So the valley will perish and the plain will be devastated

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "blood" represents a person's life. And "shedding blood" is an idiom that means to kill. Alternate translation: "from killing people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: from shedding blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Moab" represents the people. Alternate translation: "Then the people of Moab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Then Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel's descendants. See how you translated this in [Jeremiah 2:4](../02/04.md). Alternate translation: "the Israelites" or "the Israelite people group" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words "staff" and "rod" represent the power and political support that Moab provided to other nations. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Moab's enemies have ended her great power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: the strong staff, the honored rod, has been broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Moab" represents the people. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "The people are disgraced, for the enemy army has destroyed Moab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Moab has been shamed, for it has been shattered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Israel" represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "the people of Israel ... Were they found ... at them ... about them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Israel ... Was he found ... at him ... about him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents a person's inner being. Alternate translation: "his conceit" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the conceit in his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "his" refers to Moab which represents the people of Moab. Alternate translation: "their defiant speech ... like their deeds" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: his defiant speech ... like his deeds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Moab represents the people. To turn one's back is a sign of feeling ashamed. Alternate translation: "The people of Moab turn their backs in shame" or "The people of Moab are ashamed and will not show their faces" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: Moab turns its back in shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hearts" represent a person's emotions. Alternate translation: "Moab's soldiers will be afraid like a woman about to give birth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hearts of Moab's soldiers will be like the hearts of women in birth labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "in the shadow" represents protection or shelter. Alternate translation: "will hide in Heshbon for protection" or "will go to Heshbon for shelter" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: will stand in the shadow of Heshbon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Molech" represents the people who worship Molech. Alternate translation: "Why do the people who worship Molech" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Why does Molech

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Israel" represents the people of Israel. "Those" refers to people of Ammon, who represent the land that they took from Israel. Alternate translation: "Then the people of Israel will again possess the land that the people of Ammon took away from them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: For Israel will possess those who possessed him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Esau" represents the people of Edom. The Edomites were descendants of Esau. Alternate translation: "I will cause the people of Edom to experience disaster when I punish them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I am bringing the disaster of Esau on him at the time that I punish him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Esau" represents the people of Edom. Alternate translation: "the people of Edom ... their hiding ... they will not ... hide themselves ... Their children ... they are gone" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Esau ... his hiding ... he will not ... hide himself ... His children ... he is gone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the cup" is a metonym that represents the contents in the cup that the people must drink. The people experiencing Yahweh's punishment is spoken of as if Yahweh's punishment were liquid in a cup and the people must drink it. Alternate translation: "must certainly experience my punishment ... for you will certainly experience my punishment" or "I will certainly still punish ... for I will certainly punish you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: must certainly drink some of the cup ... for you will certainly drink

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heart" represents the whole person. People deceiving themselves is spoken of as if their pride deceived them. Alternate translation: "you have become prideful, but you have deceived yourselves" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your heart's pride has deceived you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Edom" represents the people. "It" refers to the land. Alternate translation: "the people of Edom will run from their land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Edom run from it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hearts" represent a person's emotions. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Jeremiah 48:41](../48/41.md). Alternate translation: "Edom's soldiers will be afraid like a woman about to give birth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the hearts of Edom's soldiers will become like the heart of a woman in birth labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Hamath" and "Arpad" represent the people who live there. Alternate translation: "The people who live in Hamath and Arpad will be ashamed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Hamath and Arpad will be ashamed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Damascus" represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: "The people of Damascus have become very weak. They turn ... seizes them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Damascus has become very weak. It turns ... seizes it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing the enemy army to light a fire is spoken of as if Yahweh will light the fire. Alternate translation: "I will cause the enemy army to light a fire" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will light a fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Nebuchadnezzar" represents his army. Alternate translation: "the army of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon was going to attack" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon was going to attack

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "nation" represents the people living there. Alternate translation: "Attack this nation, whose people feel safe and secure" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Attack the nation at ease, that lives in safety

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are a metonym for Yahweh causing enemies to destroy Elam. Alternate translation: "I will cause Elam's enemies to destroy Elam" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will shatter Elam

contextId.occurrenceNote: the people of Elam (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Elam

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents the enemy army carrying their weapons. Alternate translation: "the enemy army to pursue and kill them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the sword after them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "throne" represents Yahweh's right to rule and judge as the king. Alternate translation: "I will judge the people of Elam" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will put my throne in Elam

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah speaks of the people who live in the city of Babylon as if they were the city itself, and he speaks of the city as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "The people of Babylon have surrendered ... they have done" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: She has surrendered ... she has done

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "sword" refers to the armies that will attack Babylon. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from the oppressor's sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers collectively to all the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the army of the king of Assyria. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the army of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "land" is a metonym for the people who live in the land of Babylon. Alternate translation: "the Babylonian people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: his land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers collectively to all the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "the people of Israel to their homeland ... they will be satisfied" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Israel to his homeland ... he will be satisfied

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to having a sword come down on people to kill them. Alternate translation: "Kill them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Put them to the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "sword" represents war. Yahweh speaks of Babylon's enemies killing them in battle as if he were placing those people under the sword's power. Alternate translation: "Kill them in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Put them to the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: These sounds are heard during battle and great destruction. They are spoken of in the present tense to indicate that this will certainly happen soon. Alternate translation: "The sounds of fierce battle and terrible destruction are going to happen soon in the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The sounds of battle and enormous destruction are in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's anger that causes him to send enemies against Babylon is spoken of as if Yahweh had an armory and weapons. To open an armory is a metonym for preparing for battle. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has prepared for war and is sending the nations to attack Babylon in his anger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh has opened his armory and is bringing out the weapons for carrying out his anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the land" is a metonym for the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: "in order that the people who live in Israel might live in peace" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in order to bring rest to the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents war. Alternate translation: "War will soon happen to ... and to" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: A sword is against ... and against

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents war. Alternate translation: "War will soon happen to" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: A sword against

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents war. Alternate translation: "War will soon happen to" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: A sword is coming against

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the Babylonian people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: daughter of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "Israel" and "Judah" are metonyms for the people of Israel and Judah. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "Yahweh of hosts, the God of the people of Israel and Judah, has not forsaken them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Israel and Judah are not forsaken by their God, by Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name of the city is a metonym for the people who live there, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "the people of Babylon ... they are not healed ... leave them ... their guilt" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Babylon ... she is not healed ... leave her ... her guilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jacob" represents the people of Israel. God being their "portion" is an idiom that means that they worship him. Alternate translation: "the portion of Israel" or "whom the people of Israel worship" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the portion of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises. See how "I will attack the inhabitants of the land with my hand" is translated in [Jeremiah 6:12](../06/12.md). Alternate translation: "I will use my strength to attack you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will stretch out my hand against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Babylon is a metonym for the people of Babylon, and it is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "attack the people of Babylon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: attack her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land is a metonym for the people who live on the land. Shaking and being in anguish are metonyms for being very afraid. Alternate translation: "the people who live in Babylon will shake with fear and be in anguish" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the land will shake and be in anguish

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Babylon is a metonym for the people of Babylon. Alternate translation: "against the people of Babylon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: against Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Daughter of Babylon" here is another name for the people who live in Babylon. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The daughter of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "praise" is a metonym for the thing that people praised, and the word "earth" is a metonym for the people living on the earth. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "enemies have seized Babylon, the nation that everyone on earth praised" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: the praise of all the earth is seized

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bel was the main god of the Babylonians and represents the whole country and the people that worshiped it. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will punish Bel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ruler is a metonym for the nations under his control. Alternate translation: "Nations will fight against other nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Ruler will be against ruler

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "the people of Babylon ... their land ... their slaughtered ones ... their midst" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Babylon ... her land ... her slaughtered ones ... her midst

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "over the Babylonians ... come for them ... the Babylonians have made ... their land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: over Babylon ... come for her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "the people of Babylon ... their land ... their slaughtered ones ... their midst ... over the Babylonians ... come for them ... the Babylonians have made ... their land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Babylon has made ... her land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sword is a metonym for war, in which soldiers use swords. Alternate translation: "You who have survived the war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Survivors of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "their carved idols ... their land ... the Babylonians ... their highest fortresses ... to them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: her carved idols ... her land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "their highest fortresses ... to them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: her highest fortresses ... to her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "destroying the people of Babylon ... their loud voices" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: destroying Babylon ... her loud voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "against the people of Babylon—yes, against Babylon!—and their warriors" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: against her—against Babylon!—and her warriors

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are spoken of as if they were the city itself, and the city is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "their princes, their sages, their officials, and their soldiers ... their high gates ... their aid ... for them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: her princes, her sages, her officials, and her soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Babylon is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "their high gates ... their aid ... for them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: her high gates ... her aid ... for her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The reader should understand that removing his prison clothes represents making him a free man. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: removed Jehoiachin's prison clothes
